Topic.Title: What has happened to this Board?

Message.Msg: argh at least two posters on ignore . . d'uh . . . This is my brain, this is my brain on OBD . . . at least it still works for most things. And I can see math now (visualize complex equations) as long as I understand the math itself (e.g. no tensor equations or chaos functions, just plain 4 dimensional calculus is about my limit). Tradeoffs you know. My short term memory stinks, but its become easier to access my older long term memories. When I was in the service I expected a great deal more change than what I've actually seen over the last 30 years since. There have been, however, changes I didn't anticipate that more than make up for the ones I did.

Brawl Erupts At East St. Louis Food Stamp Office A dispute over a spot in line at a food stamp office downstate escalated into a full-fledged brawl. The fight on Tuesday was captured on video and shows at least four women wrestling and punching each other. At one point, the video shows two women grabbing each other while a third punches one of them on the back of the head. At another point, a woman walks across the office and punches another person in the face. Security officers struggled to end the chaos. It took them several minutes to separate the group and restore order. Some of the people involved in the fight initially refused to leave. The incident happened at the Illinois Department of Human Services office in East St. Louis, reportedly only a few blocks from the police station there.

Message.Title: The worst company ever!!!
Message.Msg: They should have listen to Citadel and sell the company two year ago. A lot of the companies are recovered after crash but ETFC.

Bill, I'm not trying to spin anything. Just trying to get facts. You are shooting from the hip and so am I. Please feel free to correct I say that is wrong and I will try to correct you as well. My recollection is that AMTD and SCHW both showed declines in DARTS. How did ETFC do relative to them?

Topic.Title: Finally, Didn't hold a single share into CC

Message.Msg: I predict that we will see capitulation tomorrow and perhaps into early next week...which will create the new floor in the stock. 2013 WILL be the turnaround year. Lower interest costs + lower write-downs + flat- to slightly-improving NIM = increasing share price JMHO

Bill, I'm not trying to spin anything. Just trying to understand the facts and this performance doesn't strike me as out of line given the situation. All of the brokerage firms are showing declines in trading. ETFC has been without a CEO, has a huge built-in-loss in the form of those mortgages and they still earned a decent profit when one strips out the one-time cost associated with retiring the loan payoff. I don't have an opinion on the share price but I do want to evaluate the situation fairly before coming to an opinion and lets face it, few do that with ETFC.

Just saying in a broad sense......Shareholders are the giant cow and the managers at Etrade each have a teet in their mouth. They have for a long time. Horrible performance with huge pay packages. Major problem for investors in this stock.

Message.Title: E*Trade earnings, or lack of... and you wonder why
Message.Msg: Folks on this board find other things to talk about... I wouldn't be surprised if the new CEO wants to get back in to making new home loans. E*Trade posts wider-than-expected 4th qtr loss NEW YORK Jan 24 (Reuters) - E*Trade Financial Corp , which last week named a new chief executive to help it shed bad loans and return to its online brokerage roots, on Thursday reported a fourth-quarter loss that topped Wall Street views, as its retirement of debt cost it $257 million. The company reported a loss of $186 million, or 65 cents a share, for the fourth quarter.

Topic.Title: Income From Ops - Doubled

Message.Msg: Granted they missed. That said, look at the big picture. New CEO. Obviously clearing the decks with asset writedowns (that should have occurred long ago). Basically a kitchen sink quarter for the new CEO. Look at the major holders: Citadel, Omega, TPG Axon... not guys you take lightly. They eat their young for a dime. TPG Axon, led by an ex Goldman principal genius, has almost 4% of it's fund in ETFC. Don't think he's looking to sink his fund. Tomorrow may well be rocky, but look at the facts, the past garbage is being recognized and written off, the continuing business is improving, and a new CEO has come in no doubt with great incentives. Two years from now, this thing will be gold.

Topic.Title: Income From Ops - Doubled

Message.Msg: This company isn't terribly hard to understand but it is important to look at closely because if you don't it is easy to develop a misunderstanding of the situation. 1) Have a core on-line brokerage business that is very profitable and worth substantially more than what its carrying value. Long future stream of income. 2) Have the home loans that are worth significantly less than what they are carried at. There is still risk here and losses to be booked. 3) The parent company, the owner of each of these two separate businesses faced a liquidity crisis during the bubble and had to borrow money at an extremely high interest rate and carried pre-payment penalties. They indicated the effective interest rate was 17% in the call. In effect, #2 and #3 were large losses incurred during the housing bubble explosion that weren't booked under the accounting rules and have been dribbling out for years. Number 3 is now completely booked and it was huge; there is nothing left to come. They are going to begin reporting substantial profits beginning next quarter. That is a fact and headlines talking about "wider than expected losses" are just a way of grabbing reader's attention. Kind of the equivalent of saying "E-Trade expected to become wildly profitable in future" as I was hoping for.

Topic.Title: Income From Ops - Doubled

Message.Msg: On the loans I should have said that they were prohibited from pre-paying prior to the time they paid it off. When they did pay it off there were large penalties paid, hence the loss this quarter.

Topic.Title: Audit trail leads to Koch bros.

Message.Msg: American Thinker, Karin McQuillan: "As more and more scientific evidence is published that debunks global warming, the enforced consensus is ending. The Royal Society, Britain's premier scientific institution -- whose previous president declared that "the debate on climate change is over" -- "is being forced to review its statements on climate change after a rebellion by members who question mankind's contribution to rising temperatures. ... The society has been accused by 43 of its Fellows of refusing to accept dissenting views on climate change and exaggerating the degree of certainty that man-made emissions are the main cause." Most of the rebels were retired, as one of them explained, "One of the reasons people like myself are willing to put our heads above the parapet is that our careers are not at risk from being labeled a denier or flat-Earther because we say the science is not settled. The bullying of people into silence has unfortunately been effective." In America, Dr. Ivar Giaever, a Nobel Prize-winner in physics, resigned in protest from the American Physical Society this fall because of the Society's policy statement: "The evidence is incontrovertible: global warming is occurring." Dr. Giaver: Incontrovertible is not a scientific word. Nothing is incontrovertible in science. In the APS it is ok to discuss whether the mass of the proton changes over time and how a multi-universe behaves, but the evidence of global warming is incontrovertible? The claim (how can you measure the average temperature of the whole earth for a whole year?) is that the temperature has changed from ~288.0 to ~288.8 degree Kelvin in about 150 years, which (if true) means to me is that the temperature has been amazingly stable, and both human health and happiness have definitely improved in this "warming" period. In 2008, Prof. Giaever endorsed Barack Obama's candidacy, but he has since joined 100 scientists who wrote an open letter to Obama, declaring: "We maintain that the case for alarm regarding climate change is grossly overstated."

Topic.Title: Any Reason To Hold This Stock

Message.Msg: They issued too much stock after the bubble burst to ever hope to get back to the pre-split levels. We all have losses like that from time to time and I find I feel better after having sold those positions. Consider the tax consequences before selling though. Trigger a capital gain if the loss is more than $3,000 or if you don't have a capital gain and the loss is more than $3,000 maybe just continue to hold.

Topic.Title: Any Reason To Hold This Stock

Message.Msg: Loss is over 3K will have to hold this for many years to come. Did not trade for a small profit when I had the chance.

Topic.Title: Any Reason To Hold This Stock

Message.Msg: No way to get things perfect. Even though I feel pretty confident that ETFC is undervalued "when benchmarked against other firms" there is always the possibility that those other firms are overvalued or most likely I'm just missing something. ETFC carries a market cap of $3 billion so even though I am pretty sure that beginning next quarter they will begin to generate material profits, I really don't know that the present value of their future earnings justify the current share price. Time will tell.

Topic.Title: Any Reason To Hold This Stock

Message.Msg: An article suggested that the loan loss portfolio could reverse and become an asset as real estate prices rebound which would cause the stock price to surge dramatically... is this realistic

Topic.Title: Any Reason To Hold This Stock

Message.Msg: I like buying stuff that everyone else is buying as going with the crowd is so much more comfortable. Having said that, it isn't an investment strategy IMO. There is a lot of stuff about to start going ETFC's way, maybe the share price already reflects those things. $3 billion isn't cheap but it seems reasonable and in today's market I don't expect cheap.
